Ops.Name: err
Ops.Doc: Error. Panic immediately. This is primarily a fencepost against accidental zero bytes getting compiled into programs.

Ops.Name: sha256
Ops.Doc: SHA256 hash of value X, yields [32]byte

Ops.Name: keccak256
Ops.Doc: Keccak256 hash of value X, yields [32]byte

Ops.Name: sha512_256
Ops.Doc: SHA512_256 hash of value X, yields [32]byte

Ops.Name: ed25519verify
Ops.Doc: for (data A, signature B, pubkey C) verify the signature of ("ProgData" || program_hash || data) against the pubkey => {0 or 1}
Ops.DocExtra: The 32 byte public key is the last element on the stack, preceded by the 64 byte signature at the second-to-last element on the stack, preceded by the data which was signed at the third-to-last element on the stack.

Ops.Doc: A plus B. Panic on overflow.
Ops.DocExtra: Overflow is an error condition which halts execution and fails the transaction. Full precision is available from `addw`.

Ops.Doc: A minus B. Panic if B > A.
A divided by B. Panic if B == 0.
A times B. Panic on overflow.
Ops.DocExtra: Overflow is an error condition which halts execution and fails the transaction. Full precision is available from `mulw`.

Ops.Name: <
Ops.Doc: A less than B => {0 or 1}

Ops.Name: >
Ops.Doc: A greater than B => {0 or 1}

Ops.Name: <=
Ops.Doc: A less than or equal to B => {0 or 1}

Ops.Name: >=
Ops.Doc: A greater than or equal to B => {0 or 1}

Ops.Name: &&
Ops.Doc: A is not zero and B is not zero => {0 or 1}
A is not zero or B is not zero => {0 or 1}
A is equal to B => {0 or 1}
A is not equal to B => {0 or 1}
X == 0 yields 1; else 0

Ops.Name: len
Ops.Doc: yields length of byte value X

Ops.Name: itob
Ops.Doc: converts uint64 X to big endian bytes

Ops.Name: btoi
Ops.Doc: converts bytes X as big endian to uint64
Ops.DocExtra: `btoi` panics if the input is longer than 8 bytes.

Ops.Doc: A modulo B. Panic if B == 0.
A bitwise-or B

Ops.Name: &
Ops.Doc: A bitwise-and B
A bitwise-xor B
bitwise invert value X

Ops.Name: mulw
Ops.Doc: A times B out to 128-bit long result as low (top) and high uint64 values on the stack

Ops.Name: addw
Ops.Doc: A plus B out to 128-bit long result as sum (top) and carry-bit uint64 values on the stack

Ops.Name: intcblock
Ops.Doc: prepare block of uint64 constants for use by intc
Ops.DocExtra: `intcblock` loads following program bytes into an array of integer constants in the evaluator. These integer constants can be referred to by `intc` and `intc_*` which will push the value onto the stack. Subsequent calls to `intcblock` reset and replace the integer constants available to the script.

Ops.Name: intc
Ops.Doc: push Ith constant from intcblock to stack

Ops.Name: intc_0
Ops.Doc: push constant 0 from intcblock to stack

Ops.Name: intc_1
Ops.Doc: push constant 1 from intcblock to stack

Ops.Name: intc_2
Ops.Doc: push constant 2 from intcblock to stack

Ops.Name: intc_3
Ops.Doc: push constant 3 from intcblock to stack

Ops.Name: bytecblock
Ops.Doc: prepare block of byte-array constants for use by bytec
Ops.DocExtra: `bytecblock` loads the following program bytes into an array of byte-array constants in the evaluator. These constants can be referred to by `bytec` and `bytec_*` which will push the value onto the stack. Subsequent calls to `bytecblock` reset and replace the bytes constants available to the script.

Ops.Name: bytec
Ops.Doc: push Ith constant from bytecblock to stack

Ops.Name: bytec_0
Ops.Doc: push constant 0 from bytecblock to stack

Ops.Name: bytec_1
Ops.Doc: push constant 1 from bytecblock to stack

Ops.Name: bytec_2
Ops.Doc: push constant 2 from bytecblock to stack

Ops.Name: bytec_3
Ops.Doc: push constant 3 from bytecblock to stack

Ops.Name: arg
Ops.Doc: push Nth LogicSig argument to stack

Ops.Name: arg_0
Ops.Doc: push LogicSig argument 0 to stack

Ops.Name: arg_1
Ops.Doc: push LogicSig argument 1 to stack

Ops.Name: arg_2
Ops.Doc: push LogicSig argument 2 to stack

Ops.Name: arg_3
Ops.Doc: push LogicSig argument 3 to stack

Ops.Name: txn
Ops.Doc: push field F of current transaction to stack
Ops.DocExtra: FirstValidTime causes the program to fail. The field is reserved for future use.

Ops.Name: global
Ops.Doc: push value from globals to stack

Ops.Name: gtxn
Ops.Doc: push field F of the Tth transaction in the current group
Ops.DocExtra: for notes on transaction fields available, see `txn`. If this transaction is _i_ in the group, `gtxn i field` is equivalent to `txn field`.
Ops.ImmediateNote: {uint8 transaction group index} {uint8 transaction field index}

Ops.Name: load
Ops.Doc: copy a value from scratch space to the stack
Ops.ImmediateNote: {uint8 position in scratch space to load from}

Ops.Name: store
Ops.Doc: pop a value from the stack and store to scratch space
Ops.ImmediateNote: {uint8 position in scratch space to store to}

Ops.Name: txna
Ops.Doc: push Ith value of the array field F of the current transaction
Ops.ImmediateNote: {uint8 transaction field index} {uint8 transaction field array index}

Ops.Name: gtxna
Ops.Doc: push Ith value of the array field F from the Tth transaction in the current group
Ops.ImmediateNote: {uint8 transaction group index} {uint8 transaction field index} {uint8 transaction field array index}

Ops.Name: gtxns
Ops.Doc: push field F of the Ath transaction in the current group
Ops.DocExtra: for notes on transaction fields available, see `txn`. If top of stack is _i_, `gtxns field` is equivalent to `gtxn _i_ field`. gtxns exists so that _i_ can be calculated, often based on the index of the current transaction.

Ops.Name: gtxnsa
Ops.Doc: push Ith value of the array field F from the Ath transaction in the current group
Ops.ImmediateNote: {uint8 transaction field index} {uint8 transaction field array index}

Ops.Name: bnz
Ops.Doc: branch to TARGET if value X is not zero
Ops.DocExtra:
The `bnz` instruction opcode 0x40 is followed by two immediate data bytes which are a high byte first and low byte second which together form a 16 bit offset which the instruction may branch to. For a bnz instruction at `pc`, if the last element of the stack is not zero then branch to instruction at `pc + 3 + N`, else proceed to next instruction at `pc + 3`. Branch targets must be well aligned instructions. (e.g. Branching to the second byte of a 2 byte op will be rejected.) Branch offsets are currently limited to forward branches only, 0-0x7fff. A future expansion might make this a signed 16 bit integer allowing for backward branches and looping.

At LogicSigVersion 2 it became allowed to branch to the end of the program exactly after the last instruction: bnz to byte N (with 0-indexing) was illegal for a TEAL program with N bytes before LogicSigVersion 2, and is legal after it. This change eliminates the need for a last instruction of no-op as a branch target at the end. (Branching beyond the end--in other words, to a byte larger than N--is still illegal and will cause the program to fail.)

Ops.Name: bz
Ops.Doc: branch to TARGET if value X is zero
Ops.DocExtra: See `bnz` for details on how branches work. `bz` inverts the behavior of `bnz`.

Ops.Name: b
Ops.Doc: branch unconditionally to TARGET
Ops.DocExtra: See `bnz` for details on how branches work. `b` always jumps to the offset.

Ops.Name: return
Ops.Doc: use last value on stack as success value; end

Ops.Name: assert
Ops.Doc: immediately fail unless value X is a non-zero number

Ops.Name: pop
Ops.Doc: discard value X from stack

Ops.Name: dup
Ops.Doc: duplicate last value on stack

Ops.Name: dup2
Ops.Doc: duplicate two last values on stack: A, B -> A, B, A, B

Ops.Name: dig
Ops.Doc: push the Nth value from the top of the stack. dig 0 is equivalent to dup

Ops.Name: swap
Ops.Doc: swaps two last values on stack: A, B -> B, A

Ops.Name: select
Ops.Doc: selects one of two values based on top-of-stack: A, B, C -> (if C != 0 then B else A)

Ops.Name: concat
Ops.Doc: pop two byte-arrays A and B and join them, push the result
Ops.DocExtra: `concat` panics if the result would be greater than 4096 bytes.

Ops.Name: substring
Ops.Doc: pop a byte-array A. For immediate values in 0..255 S and E: extract a range of bytes from A starting at S up to but not including E, push the substring result. If E < S, or either is larger than the array length, the program fails

Ops.Name: substring3
Ops.Doc: pop a byte-array A and two integers B and C. Extract a range of bytes from A starting at B up to but not including C, push the substring result. If C < B, or either is larger than the array length, the program fails

Ops.Name: getbit
Ops.Doc: pop a target A (integer or byte-array), and index B. Push the Bth bit of A.
Ops.DocExtra: see explanation of bit ordering in setbit

Ops.Name: setbit
Ops.Doc: pop a target A, index B, and bit C. Set the Bth bit of A to C, and push the result
Ops.DocExtra: bit indexing begins with low-order bits in integers. Setting bit 4 to 1 on the integer 0 yields 16 (`int 0x0010`, or 2^4). Indexing begins in the first bytes of a byte-string (as seen in getbyte and substring). Setting bits 0 through 11 to 1 in a 4 byte-array of 0s yields `byte 0xfff00000`

Ops.Name: getbyte
Ops.Doc: pop a byte-array A and integer B. Extract the Bth byte of A and push it as an integer

Ops.Name: setbyte
Ops.Doc: pop a byte-array A, integer B, and small integer C (between 0..255). Set the Bth byte of A to C, and push the result

Ops.Name: balance
Ops.Doc: get balance for the requested account specified by Txn.Accounts[A] in microalgos. A is specified as an account index in the Accounts field of the ApplicationCall transaction, zero index means the sender. The balance is observed after the effects of previous transactions in the group, and after the fee for the current transaction is deducted.

Ops.Name: app_opted_in
Ops.Doc: check if account specified by Txn.Accounts[A] opted in for the application B => {0 or 1}
Ops.DocExtra: params: account index, application id (top of the stack on opcode entry). Return: 1 if opted in and 0 otherwise.

Ops.Name: app_local_get
Ops.Doc: read from account specified by Txn.Accounts[A] from local state of the current application key B => value
Ops.DocExtra: params: account index, state key. Return: value. The value is zero (of type uint64) if the key does not exist.

Ops.Name: app_local_get_ex
Ops.Doc: read from account specified by Txn.Accounts[A] from local state of the application B key C => [*... stack*, value, 0 or 1]
Ops.DocExtra: params: account index, application id, state key. Return: did_exist flag (top of the stack, 1 if exist and 0 otherwise), value. The value is zero (of type uint64) if the key does not exist.

Ops.Name: app_global_get
Ops.Doc: read key A from global state of a current application => value
Ops.DocExtra: params: state key. Return: value. The value is zero (of type uint64) if the key does not exist.

Ops.Name: app_global_get_ex
Ops.Doc: read from application Txn.ForeignApps[A] global state key B => [*... stack*, value, 0 or 1]. A is specified as an account index in the ForeignApps field of the ApplicationCall transaction, zero index means this app
Ops.DocExtra: params: application index, state key. Return: did_exist flag (top of the stack, 1 if exist and 0 otherwise), value. The value is zero (of type uint64) if the key does not exist.

Ops.Name: app_local_put
Ops.Doc: write to account specified by Txn.Accounts[A] to local state of a current application key B with value C
Ops.DocExtra: params: account index, state key, value.

Ops.Name: app_global_put
Ops.Doc: write key A and value B to global state of the current application

Ops.Name: app_local_del
Ops.Doc: delete from account specified by Txn.Accounts[A] local state key B of the current application
Ops.DocExtra:
params: account index, state key.

Deleting a key which is already absent has no effect on the application local state. (In particular, it does _not_ cause the program to fail.)

Ops.Name: app_global_del
Ops.Doc: delete key A from a global state of the current application
Ops.DocExtra:
params: state key.

Deleting a key which is already absent has no effect on the application global state. (In particular, it does _not_ cause the program to fail.)

Ops.Name: asset_holding_get
Ops.Doc: read from account specified by Txn.Accounts[A] and asset B holding field X (imm arg) => {0 or 1 (top), value}
Ops.DocExtra: params: account index, asset id. Return: did_exist flag (1 if exist and 0 otherwise), value.

Ops.Name: asset_params_get
Ops.Doc: read from asset Txn.ForeignAssets[A] params field X (imm arg) => {0 or 1 (top), value}
Ops.DocExtra: params: txn.ForeignAssets offset. Return: did_exist flag (1 if exist and 0 otherwise), value.

Ops.Name: min_balance
Ops.Doc: get minimum required balance for the requested account specified by Txn.Accounts[A] in microalgos. A is specified as an account index in the Accounts field of the ApplicationCall transaction, zero index means the sender. Required balance is affected by [ASA](https://developer.algorand.org/docs/features/asa/#assets-overview) and [App](https://developer.algorand.org/docs/features/asc1/stateful/#minimum-balance-requirement-for-a-smart-contract) usage. When creating or opting into an app, the minimum balance grows before the app code runs, therefore the increase is visible there. When deleting or closing out, the minimum balance decreases after the app executes.

Ops.Name: pushbytes
Ops.Doc: push the following program bytes to the stack

Ops.Name: pushint
Ops.Doc: push immediate UINT to the stack as an integer
